div.p: HAving con≈øidered, that the weakne≈ø≈øe, and frivolou≈øne≈ø≈øe, of the Arguments brought by A. But further con≈øidering, that the ≈øaid Arguments of his, were divulged in print, and might do much hurt among≈øt ≈øome ignorant people, who would do better if they knew better; I thought it meet to help to take off this new vizard, put upon the Anabapti≈øts old out-worn arguments, and ≈øo to pull down this little tottering turret of Babel; becau≈øe that in this fal≈øe fire, and light of the ≈øparks of the≈øe crackling thornes, the makers thereof delight ≈øtill to walke, and ≈øome are yet deluded, by ≈øuch frothie Divinitie, and ≈ømokie clouds of ≈øubl me ≈øophi≈øtry; without due triall of them, by the light of Gods Word; or weighing them in the balance of the Sanctuary.

Wherefore, in obedience to God, and love to his people; I have here undertaken to u≈øe my talent in vindicating the lawfulne≈ø≈øe of Chri≈øtians Bapti≈øme, rai≈øed with them out of the grave of the Apo≈øta≈øie of the man of ≈øinne, which hath been for many yeers, in which Apo≈øtate e≈øtate, and wretched condition, the name of God hath been greatly profained, his in≈øtitutions (though not de≈øtroyed) yet highly abu≈øed, to the de≈øtruction of many ≈øouls; out of which ≈øtate, God hath called ≈øome, who have obeyed his voyce, and come out of Babel to Sion; and are as dearly beloved of God, as the penitent I≈øraelites, whom God in former time brought from Jeroboams apo≈øta≈øie to Judah, where they kept the fea≈øt, unto the Lord, and were both young, and old, accepted of him, though they retained the Circumci≈øion which they received in that apo≈øtate e≈øtate, where there was neither true vi≈øible Church, mini≈øtry, wor≈øhip, nor government, but all diabolicall, and Apo≈øtaticall: yet (God having re≈øerved his own ordinance pure unto him≈øelf) the evill of the manner being repented of, by them;
the thing it ≈øelf was not commanded to be admini≈øtred upon them again.

And ≈øurely, God could have commanded that Circum ‚Ä¢ i≈øion [done in Apo≈øta≈øie, by a wrong admini≈øtrator, and by a fal≈øe power, and upon a wrong ≈øubject,] to have been e≈øteemed as not done at all, and that the parties when they returned from that Apo≈øta≈øie, ≈øhould have been circumci≈øed again; but he would not, no more hath he commanded us to be bapti≈øed again, though we were bapti≈øed in an Apo≈øtate ≈øtate: for Bapti≈øme is as durable as Circumci≈øion, and God is as able to purge bapti≈øme now, as he was to purge Circumci≈øion then.

But Mr. A. R. hath taken upon him to prove the Bapti≈øme which we Chri≈øtians received (in the ≈øtate of Apo≈øta≈øie) to be none of Gods Bapti≈øme; but in≈øufficient; In the pro≈øecution whereof, he alledgeth ≈øeverall particulars, by which he would di≈øprove the ≈øame: which particulars are examined, and his inferences from thence an≈øwered in the en≈øuing di≈øcour≈øe.

But it would not have been ami≈ø≈øe, if he had well con≈øidered (for abridgement of his work) that bapti≈øme, being (by his own confe≈ø≈øion) a great ordinance of the New Te≈øtament; To make it le≈ø≈øe generall, or le≈ø≈øe durable then Circumci≈øion, or inferiour thereunto, would be to make Chri≈øt le≈ø≈øe faithfull in his hou≈øe then Mo≈øes; and inferiour to him: But bapti≈øme is more generall then Circumci≈øion: And Chri≈øt is more excellent then Mo≈øes, and Bapti≈øme is as durable as Circumci≈øion. Therefore ≈øeeing Circumci≈øion was not worne out by tho≈øe; Bapti≈øme is not worne out by the≈øe.

Think not (Chri≈øtian Reader) that I intend to plead for the Apo≈øtaticall Church of Rome, or any of her daughters, or for their mini≈øtry, wor≈øhip, or Government! So farre am I from this, that I utterly renounce, and di≈øclaime the ≈øame; and leave the Ju≈øtification of them to the di≈øpo≈øition of tho≈øe who account them no wor≈øe then Heathens that never knew the truth; and ≈øeek to le≈ø≈øen their ≈øinne by labouring to vindicate their ≈øuppo≈øed innocencie, teaching them [in this] to plead ignoramus, and not guiltie, when they are ju≈øtly accu≈øed for committing of ≈øacriledge. Yea, and Gods definitive ≈øentence pronounced again≈øt them, and his just judgements executed (and daily executing) upon them, as appeareth at this very day, ≈øince the ≈øharp arrows of the Almighty have been (and are ≈øtill) ≈øo generally ≈øcattered abroad, to the de≈øtruction, and ruination of tho≈øe per≈øons; not onely for their abu≈øe of common meats, and drinks, and other temporall ble≈ø≈øings; but chiefly (and above all) for the abu≈øe and prophanation of ≈øpirituall things, as (the prophanation of) Gods holy word, and ordinances, which they di≈øtribute to all ≈øorts of ≈øinners that come under
the notion of a verball profe≈ø≈øion, though very vile in their life and conver≈øation. All which is of us not to be le≈ø≈øened, or excu≈øed, as if it were not ≈øacriledge (or theft in an high degree) but rather to be lamented, that tho≈øe per≈øons who draw neer unto God with their mouthes, and outwardly pretend to ≈øtand for Chri≈øt, and fight for his true Religion; (taking upon them to defend the ≈øame, ≈øome with the Word, others with the ≈øword) again≈øt tho≈øe who do oppo≈øe them) ≈øhould have their hearts ≈øo farre alienated from God, as ≈øo much to take his holy Name in vaine, and prophane his Sabbaths, as tho≈øe do who on that day powre out their meat-offerings and drink-offerings, in the idolatrous high places, which being a defilement unto the Land, are by the laws of God de≈øtinated to de≈øtruction. For the≈øe and the like abominations (I ≈øay) we ought to mourneEzek. 9.: and that they ≈øhould ≈øo ≈øteal his ordinances, and abu≈øe his Word, to the de≈øtruction and ruination, ≈øpuing, and rooting out of them≈øelves, and their po≈øteritie, from tho≈øe good and fruitfull lands wherein God of his mercie had planted them.

The≈øe and the like evils, were the cau≈øes why God did bring upon his people I≈ørael of old, divers heavie and ≈øore judgements, as pe≈øtilence, famine, and ≈øword, and wilde bea≈øts to devoure both them and theirs, yea though they were circumci≈øed in fle≈øh, yet becau≈øe they were not circumci≈øed in heart, God threatned to vi≈øit them with the uncircumci≈øed in fle≈øh Jer. 9.25, 26., and make their Cities de≈øolate without inhabitants, and their hou≈øes without man and their land utterly de≈øolate: and that he would remove them farre away, and never promi≈øed to bring them againe from captivitie, nor prophe≈øied good unto any but tho≈øe who were upright in heart; even the tenth part, (or rather le≈ø≈øe) which were the holy ≈øeed, the ≈øub≈øtance I≈øa 6.11, 12, 13., and the remnant Cap 10.21..

Wherefore, it evidently appeareth, that in an idolatrous e≈øtate, and Apo≈øtate condition, there is no true comfort, or con≈øolation to be expected; though they have and enjoy bapti≈øme as of old the Jewi≈øh Apo≈øtates had, and did enjoy Circumci≈øion, but as the≈øe are ≈øinners in like manner as tho≈øe were; ≈øo the≈øe may expect the ≈øame mea≈øure of puni≈øhment (from the hand of God) as tho≈øe had: yea, con≈øidering that the≈øe have their own actuall ≈øins, lying upon themRev. 9.18.20, 21. But as the Lord hath called us out of the ≈øinke of Sodome, and grave of Babyloni≈øh and Aegyptian Apo≈øta≈øie (where our Lord was crucified;) ≈øo we mu≈øt not di≈øhonour him ≈øo farre as to ca≈øt away his holy ve≈ø≈øels, or any good thing of his which we have received; for God is able to purge tho≈øe things which are his own; upon our repentance; So that the evill manner of receiving Bapti≈øme doth not argue but that the thing in it ≈øelf is good, and may be applyed to the ≈øame end and u≈øe for which it was fir≈øt given.
